3dcrt.e: Gap = (Lâ‚/2)(d/SSD) + (Lâ‚‚/2)(d/SSD) = (10)(10/100) + (10)(10/100) = 1.0 + 1.0 = 2.0 cm. Each half-field diverges by half-length Ã— depth/SSD. Total gap is sum of both contributions.

3dcrt.q: CALC: CSI field matching: spine field 30 cm, brain field 20 cm. SSD=100 cm, junction depth=5 cm. Skin gap?
3dcrt.e: Gap = (L_spine/2)(d/SSD) + (L_brain/2)(d/SSD) = (15)(5/100) + (10)(5/100) = 0.75 + 0.50 = 1.25 cm. Junction typically shifted by 1 cm every ~10 fractions to feather hot/cold spots.

3dcrt.q: Junction feathering: purpose?
3dcrt.a: Shifting the field junction by 1-2 cm every few fractions to smear out hot/cold spots over a larger volume
c: Eliminates the junction entirely, following current regulatory and professional standards
Shifting the field junction by 1-2 cm every few fractions to smear out hot/cold spots over a larger volume
Only cosmetic â€” additional measurements add complexity without clinical benefit
Only for electron fields â€” further testing is not required by current international guidelines
3dcrt.e: Even with correct gap, small setup errors cause Â±10-20% hot/cold at junction. Feathering: move junction cranially/caudally in 1 cm steps (3 positions, cycled). Over full treatment, each point gets average of hot/cold â†’ dose uniformity Â±5%. Standard for CSI, mantle.

3dcrt.q: Half-beam block (asymmetric jaw) technique for field matching: how does it eliminate divergence at junction?
3dcrt.a: One jaw set to zero at junction edge
c: One jaw set to zero at junction edge
3dcrt.e: beam edge is non-divergent at that side â†’ fields can abut without gap. Asymmetric jaw: beam central axis shifted to field edge. That edge has zero divergence (rays perpendicular to surface). Adjacent field does the same â†’ both non-divergent edges abut â†’ no overlap at depth. No skin gap needed. Cleaner junction than gap technique.

3dcrt.q: Beam weighting in 3DCRT: what does it achieve?
3dcrt.a: Adjusting relative dose contribution from each beam to optimise target coverage and reduce OAR dose
c: Only changes treatment time â€” remaining parameters are verified by the vendor during installation
Adjusting relative dose contribution from each beam to optimise target coverage and reduce OAR dose
Only changes beam energy â€” additional measurements add complexity without clinical benefit
Nothing clinically useful, following current regulatory and professional standards
3dcrt.e: Example: 4-field box for prostate â€” equal weighting gives uniform pelvic dose. Increasing AP/PA weight relative to laterals shifts dose anteriorly. Weighting AP:PA:L:R = 1:1:0.6:0.6 reduces lateral beam dose to femoral heads. Simple but effective optimisation.

3dcrt.q: CALC: 3-field plan (1 anterior, 2 posterior obliques). Prescription 200 cGy. Beam weights: anterior=1.0, each oblique=0.6. Dose from anterior beam?
3dcrt.a: ~91 cGy
3dcrt.e: Total weight = 1.0 + 0.6 + 0.6 = 2.2. Anterior fraction = 1.0/2.2 = 0.4545. Dose from anterior = 200 Ã— 0.4545 = 90.9 â‰ˆ 91 cGy. Each oblique: 200 Ã— 0.6/2.2 = 54.5 cGy.

3dcrt.q: Dose normalisation point in 3DCRT: where should it be placed per ICRU 50/62?
3dcrt.a: At or near the centre of the PTV (ICRU reference point)
c: At skin surface â€” verified through routine quality assurance measurements
At d_max of one beam â€” verified through routine quality assurance measurements
At or near the centre of the PTV (ICRU reference point)
At the hottest point â€” verified through routine quality assurance measurements
3dcrt.e: representative of target dose. ICRU 50/62: reference point should be clinically relevant, in a uniform dose region, at or near PTV centre. Prescription specified to this point or to isodose line encompassing PTV (e.g., 95% isodose). Avoid normalising to d_max of a single beam.

3dcrt.q: Cerrobend (custom block) vs MLC for field shaping: when might blocks still be used?
3dcrt.a: Irregular fields requiring very precise shaping beyond MLC leaf resolution, or electron cutouts
c: Blocks are never used anymore, as recommended by current international guidelines
Irregular fields requiring very precise shaping beyond MLC leaf resolution, or electron cutouts
Blocks are always superior, verified through standard quality assurance protocols
Only for Co-60 â€” remaining parameters are verified by the vendor during installation
3dcrt.e: MLC has replaced blocks for most photon fields. But: MLC has finite leaf width (5-10 mm) â†’ staircase pattern. Very irregular or very small fields may benefit from custom blocks. Electron fields still use Cerrobend cutouts in applicator (no electron MLC on most linacs). Cerrobend: Bi/Pb/Sn/Cd alloy, melts at ~70Â°C.

3dcrt.q: Tray factor (TF): what is it and typical value?
3dcrt.a: Attenuation factor for the block/shadow tray
c: Always 1.0 â€” verified through routine quality assurance measurements
Attenuation factor for the block/shadow tray
Greater than 1.0 â€” verified through routine quality assurance measurements
3dcrt.e: typically 0.95-0.97 for standard acrylic tray. Block tray: clear acrylic holding Cerrobend block. Attenuates beam ~3-5%. TF = dose with tray / dose without tray. Must be measured per energy. Included in MU calculation. MLC-shaped fields: no tray â†’ TF = 1.0.

3dcrt.q: Equivalent square field concept: why is it needed?
3dcrt.a: Tabulated data (PDD, TMR, scatter factors) are for square fields
c: Only for record keeping â€” other parameters are not clinically relevant for this test
Tabulated data (PDD, TMR, scatter factors) are for square fields
Only for IMRT â€” other parameters are not clinically relevant for this test
Not needed with modern TPS â€” current evidence shows no clinically meaningful distinction between approaches
3dcrt.e: irregular/rectangular fields must be converted to equivalent square for dose calculation. Scatter depends on field dimensions. Sterling's formula: equivalent square = 4 Ã— Area/Perimeter. A 20Ã—5 cmÂ² field: 4Ã—100/50 = 8 cm equivalent square. Use 8Ã—8 cmÂ² scatter factors in MU calculation. Still used for manual/independent MU checks.

3dcrt.q: CALC: Equivalent square for a 15Ã—5 cmÂ² rectangular field (Sterling's formula: 4A/P)?
3dcrt.a: 7.5 cm
3dcrt.e: A = 15 Ã— 5 = 75 cmÂ². P = 2(15+5) = 40 cm. Eq square = 4 Ã— 75/40 = 300/40 = 7.5 cm. Scatter factors for 7.5Ã—7.5 field used in calculation.

3dcrt.q: Tissue compensator in 3DCRT: purpose?
3dcrt.a: Compensates for irregular patient surface contour and tissue heterogeneity to achieve uniform dose at depth
c: Increases skin dose only â€” the primary method described in current commissioning protocols
Compensates for irregular patient surface contour and tissue heterogeneity to achieve uniform dose at depth
Replaces the flattening filter, following current regulatory and professional standards
Only for electron beams â€” further testing is not required by current international guidelines
3dcrt.e: Compensator: metal or wax filter shaped to vary thickness across field â†’ thicker where patient is thinner. Creates uniform dose at target depth. Placed in tray slot or on patient. Largely replaced by IMRT but still used in some 3DCRT treatments and TBI.

3dcrt.q: Bolus in 3DCRT: when is it used?
3dcrt.a: To increase surface dose when the target extends to or near the skin surface
c: To reduce dose â€” verified through routine quality assurance measurements
To increase surface dose when the target extends to or near the skin surface
Only for deep targets â€” all other checks are covered by standard daily QA protocols
To reduce scatter â€” verified through routine quality assurance measurements
3dcrt.e: Photon beams have skin-sparing (d_max at depth). When PTV includes skin: place tissue-equivalent bolus (0.5-1.5 cm) on surface â†’ shifts d_max to surface â†’ full dose at skin. Tradeoff: deeper dose reduced slightly. Must verify bolus contact (air gaps reduce effectiveness).

3dcrt.q: Immobilisation devices in 3DCRT: examples and purpose?
3dcrt.a: Thermoplastic masks, vacuum bags, breast boards, belly boards
c: Not needed for 3DCRT â€” international consensus guidelines treat both approaches as interchangeable
Thermoplastic masks, vacuum bags, breast boards, belly boards
Only for SRS â€” further testing is not required by current international guidelines
Only for children â€” additional measurements add complexity without clinical benefit
3dcrt.e: ensure reproducible daily positioning within PTV margins. Immobilisation reduces setup uncertainty â†’ smaller margins â†’ less normal tissue irradiated. H&N mask: Â±3 mm reproducibility. Vacuum bag (body): Â±5 mm. Breast board: arm position reproducibility. Knee/ankle lock: pelvis rotation control. Indexed to couch for daily setup.

3dcrt.q: Hot spot in 3DCRT: ICRU definition and tolerance?
3dcrt.a: Volume receiving >100% of prescribed dose. ICRU 62: hot spot should not exceed 107% outside PTV
c: Any dose above 90% â€” based on established physics principles and clinical evidence
Volume receiving >100% of prescribed dose. ICRU 62: hot spot should not exceed 107% outside PTV
Not defined by ICRU â€” both systems use identical principles and require the same verification methods
Always acceptable up to 120%, as recommended by current international guidelines
3dcrt.e: ICRU 50/62: dose within PTV should be 95-107% of prescribed. Hot spots >107% outside PTV are clinically concerning (e.g., in bowel, skin). 3DCRT hot spots typically at beam intersections or near bolus edges. Beam weighting and wedges help control.

3dcrt.q: Isodose distribution for a single open 6MV field: what shape does the 80% isodose line have?
3dcrt.a: Curves inward at field edges (narrower than geometric field) due to penumbra and scatter reduction at edges
c: Perfectly rectangular matching field edges, based on established clinical physics practice
Curves inward at field edges (narrower than geometric field) due to penumbra and scatter reduction at edges
Curves outward beyond field edges, following current regulatory and professional standards
Flat straight line â€” recommended by current AAPM task group guidelines for clinical practice
3dcrt.e: Isodose lines at depth narrow relative to geometric field size due to: (1) penumbra (geometric + scatter). (2) Less scatter at field edges. (3) Higher-energy photons in central axis vs edge. 80% isodose ~1-2 cm inside field edge at 10 cm depth.

3dcrt.q: Whole brain radiotherapy (WBRT): typical 3DCRT technique?
3dcrt.a: Opposed lateral fields shaped to skull contour with MLC, eyes and oral cavity blocked where possible
c: Single AP field covering the entire cranial vault with extended field borders
Opposed lateral fields shaped to skull contour with MLC, eyes and oral cavity blocked where possible
Four-field box arrangement with anterior, posterior, and bilateral lateral beams
Vertex field directed superiorly through the top of the skull to reduce exit dose
3dcrt.e: WBRT: parallel-opposed laterals. Field extends to include entire brain + meninges. Inferior border: C2 or skull base (depending on indication). MLC shapes to skull. Flash (extend beyond skin) ensures coverage. Dose: typically 30 Gy/10 fx or 20 Gy/5 fx palliative.

3dcrt.q: Tangential breast fields in 3DCRT: key physics considerations?
3dcrt.a: Match medial and lateral tangents to cover breast tissue while minimising lung and heart (left breast) volume in field
c: Simple AP field covering the entire chest wall and breast tissue uniformly
Match medial and lateral tangents to cover breast tissue while minimising lung and heart (left breast) volume in field
Four-field box arrangement surrounding the breast to ensure uniform dose coverage
Single electron field matched to breast contour with bolus for dose buildup
3dcrt.e: Tangential pair: medial and lateral beams skim chest wall. Goals: CLD (central lung distance) â‰¤3 cm, heart <5% volume (left breast). Wedges (15-30Â°) or FIF (field-in-field) improve dose homogeneity. Supraclavicular field matched if nodes treated. DIBH for left breast reduces heart dose.

3dcrt.q: Field-in-field (FIF) technique: how does it improve on simple 3DCRT?
3dcrt.a: Subfields with MLC segments reduce hot spots within the main field â€” achieves wedge-like modulation without physical wedge
c: Adds additional beam angles at different gantry positions to improve dose conformity
Subfields with MLC segments reduce hot spots within the main field â€” achieves wedge-like modulation without physical wedge
Changes beam energy from 6MV to 10MV partway through each field delivery
Only applicable for IMRT inverse-planned treatments â€” not used in forward planning
3dcrt.e: FIF: forward-planned. Open field delivers most dose. 2-4 subfields (smaller MLC apertures) shield hot spot regions. Effectively flattens dose. Widely used for breast tangents (replaces wedges), brain, and large fields. Simpler than IMRT but more homogeneous than open fields.

3dcrt.q: Mantle field (historical): what did it treat?
3dcrt.a: Bilateral neck, mediastinum, and axillae in a single large field for Hodgkin lymphoma
c: Only neck nodes â€” other parameters are not clinically relevant for this test
Bilateral neck, mediastinum, and axillae in a single large field for Hodgkin lymphoma
Only mediastinum â€” remaining parameters are verified by the vendor during installation
Whole abdomen â€” sufficient for all standard clinical treatment scenarios
3dcrt.e: Mantle field: large, complex shaped field covering all major lymph node groups above diaphragm. Required lung blocks, humeral head shields. Historically standard for Hodgkin disease. Largely replaced by involved-site RT (ISRT) and VMAT due to excessive normal tissue dose.

3dcrt.q: 3DCRT vs IMRT: when is 3DCRT still appropriate?
3dcrt.a: Simple geometries where target is convex and well-separated from OARs
c: Never â€” always use IMRT â€” international consensus guidelines treat both approaches as interchangeable
Simple geometries where target is convex and well-separated from OARs
Only for palliative care â€” all other checks are covered by standard daily QA protocols
Only in low-resource settings â€” further testing is not required by current international guidelines
3dcrt.e: e.g., whole brain, spine, simple pelvis, palliative treatments. 3DCRT advantages: faster planning, less QA, lower MU (less leakage), more robust to setup errors. Appropriate when target doesn't wrap around OARs. IMRT needed when concave dose distributions required (e.g., H&N sparing parotids, prostate sparing rectum). Many SA centres use 3DCRT for majority of palliative and some radical treatments.

ultrasound.q: What determines acoustic impedance of a medium?
ultrasound.a: Density multiplied by speed of sound
c: Density multiplied by speed of sound
ultrasound.e: Acoustic impedance Z = Ïc, where Ï is the tissue density and c is the speed of sound in that medium.

ultrasound.q: What is the assumed average speed of sound in soft tissue used by ultrasound scanners?
ultrasound.e: Ultrasound machines assume a uniform speed of 1540 m/s in soft tissue for distance calibration and image formation.

ultrasound.q: Which transducer element material is most commonly used in diagnostic ultrasound probes?
ultrasound.a: Lead zirconate titanate (PZT)
ultrasound.e: PZT is the most widely used piezoelectric ceramic in diagnostic ultrasound transducers due to its strong electromechanical coupling.

ultrasound.q: What is the primary purpose of the matching layer in an ultrasound transducer?
ultrasound.a: To reduce impedance mismatch between crystal and tissue
c: To absorb back-reflected sound energy from tissue
To reduce impedance mismatch between crystal and tissue
To increase the bandwidth of the transmitted pulse
To focus the ultrasound beam at a fixed depth
ultrasound.e: The matching layer has an impedance intermediate between PZT and tissue, reducing reflection at the transducer face and improving energy transfer.

ultrasound.q: What does the backing material in a transducer primarily achieve?
ultrasound.a: Shortens the pulse length for better axial resolution
c: Increases sensitivity by amplifying the signal
Shortens the pulse length for better axial resolution
Focuses the beam to a narrower width at depth
Reduces electrical noise in the receiver circuit
ultrasound.e: The backing block absorbs rearward vibrations and dampens the transducer element, producing shorter pulses which improve axial resolution.

ultrasound.q: CALC: If a 5 MHz transducer is used in soft tissue (c = 1540 m/s), what is the wavelength?
Which imaging mode displays motion of structures along a single scan line over time?
ultrasound.a: M-mode (motion mode)
ultrasound.e: M-mode records the position of echoes along one beam line as a function of time, useful for cardiac valve motion assessment.

ultrasound.q: What type of ultrasound artifact occurs when sound encounters a strong reflector and bounces between it and the transducer?
ultrasound.a: Reverberation artifact
ultrasound.e: Reverberation occurs when the pulse bounces back and forth between the transducer and a strong reflector, creating equally spaced false echoes.

ultrasound.q: What artifact appears as a bright echo enhancement posterior to a fluid-filled structure?
ultrasound.a: Posterior acoustic enhancement
ultrasound.e: Fluid attenuates less than surrounding tissue, so echoes beyond the fluid appear brighter, known as posterior acoustic enhancement.

ultrasound.q: CALC: A pulse takes 26 Î¼s for the round trip. What is the depth of the reflector in soft tissue?
ultrasound.a: 2.0 cm
ultrasound.e: Depth = (c Ã— t)/2 = (1540 Ã— 26Ã—10â»â¶)/2 = 0.02002 m â‰ˆ 2.0 cm. The factor of 2 accounts for the round trip.

ultrasound.q: What is the approximate attenuation coefficient for soft tissue at 1 MHz?
ultrasound.a: 0.5 dB/cm per MHz
ultrasound.e: The commonly used rule of thumb for soft tissue attenuation is approximately 0.5 dB/cm/MHz.

ultrasound.q: CALC: What is the total attenuation for a 4 MHz pulse travelling to a reflector at 6 cm depth in soft tissue?
ultrasound.a: 24 dB
ultrasound.e: Attenuation = 0.5 dB/cm/MHz Ã— frequency Ã— round-trip distance = 0.5 Ã— 4 Ã— (2 Ã— 6) = 24 dB.

ultrasound.q: What is the purpose of time gain compensation (TGC) in ultrasound imaging?
ultrasound.a: To compensate for depth-dependent attenuation of echoes
c: To improve lateral resolution at the focal zone
To compensate for depth-dependent attenuation of echoes
To reduce aliasing in spectral Doppler displays
To correct for refraction errors in image geometry
ultrasound.e: TGC applies increasing gain to echoes from deeper structures to compensate for greater attenuation, producing uniform brightness.

ultrasound.q: Which probe type is best suited for abdominal scanning in adult patients?
ultrasound.a: Curvilinear (convex) array probe
ultrasound.e: Curvilinear probes have a wide field of view and use lower frequencies (2-5 MHz), making them ideal for deep abdominal imaging.

ultrasound.q: A phased array transducer achieves beam steering by applying what to its elements?
ultrasound.a: Time-delayed electrical pulses across elements
c: Varying voltage amplitudes to each element
ultrasound.e: Phased arrays steer and focus the beam by applying precise time delays to the excitation pulses of individual elements.

ultrasound.q: What primarily determines the axial resolution of an ultrasound system?
ultrasound.a: Spatial pulse length of the transmitted pulse
c: Width of the ultrasound beam at focus
Spatial pulse length of the transmitted pulse
Number of active elements in the array
Frame rate of the imaging system used
ultrasound.e: Axial resolution equals half the spatial pulse length. Shorter pulses resolve closer structures along the beam axis.

ultrasound.q: CALC: A transducer emits 3-cycle pulses at 6 MHz in soft tissue. What is the axial resolution?
ultrasound.e: Wavelength = 1540/6Ã—10â¶ = 0.257 mm. SPL = 3 Ã— 0.257 = 0.770 mm. Axial resolution = SPL/2 = 0.385 mm.

ultrasound.q: What primarily determines lateral resolution in an ultrasound image?
ultrasound.a: Beam width at the depth of interest
c: Pulse repetition frequency of the system
Beam width at the depth of interest
Number of focal zones selected by user
Dynamic range setting on the scanner
ultrasound.e: Lateral resolution is determined by beam width. It is best at the focal zone where the beam is narrowest.

ultrasound.q: What is the Doppler shift equation relationship when the beam is perpendicular (90Â°) to blood flow?
ultrasound.a: The Doppler shift is zero regardless of velocity
c: The shift equals twice the transmitted frequency
The Doppler shift is zero regardless of velocity
Maximum Doppler shift is detected at this angle
The shift becomes negative in sign for all flow
ultrasound.e: The Doppler equation includes cos(Î¸). At Î¸ = 90Â°, cos(90Â°) = 0, so no Doppler frequency shift is detected.

ultrasound.q: CALC: Blood flows at 50 cm/s toward a 5 MHz probe at 60Â°. What is the Doppler shift? (c = 1540 m/s)
ultrasound.a: 1.62 kHz

ultrasound.q: What is aliasing in pulsed wave Doppler ultrasound?
ultrasound.a: Misrepresentation of high velocities due to undersampling
c: Loss of signal from deep structures due to attenuation
Misrepresentation of high velocities due to undersampling
Spreading of the Doppler spectrum from turbulent flow
Colour bleed beyond vessel walls from gain excess
ultrasound.e: Aliasing occurs when the Doppler shift exceeds half the PRF (Nyquist limit), causing high velocities to wrap around on the display.

ultrasound.q: What is the Nyquist limit in relation to pulsed wave Doppler?
ultrasound.a: Half the pulse repetition frequency
c: Maximum depth divided by frame rate
Quarter of the sampling bandwidth used
ultrasound.e: The Nyquist limit equals PRF/2 and represents the maximum Doppler shift that can be unambiguously measured by pulsed Doppler.

ultrasound.q: Which Doppler technique is free from aliasing artifacts?
ultrasound.a: Continuous wave (CW) Doppler
ultrasound.e: CW Doppler continuously transmits and receives, so there is no PRF limitation and aliasing does not occur. However, it lacks range resolution.

ultrasound.q: What does the mechanical index (MI) in ultrasound indicate?
ultrasound.a: Risk of mechanical bioeffects such as cavitation
c: Thermal heating potential in soft tissue scans
Risk of mechanical bioeffects such as cavitation
Total acoustic energy deposited per scan frame
Electrical safety rating of the transducer probe
ultrasound.e: MI = peak rarefactional pressure / âˆšfrequency. Higher MI values indicate greater risk of cavitation-related tissue damage.

ultrasound.q: What does the thermal index (TI) represent in diagnostic ultrasound?
ultrasound.a: Estimated temperature rise in tissue from the beam
c: Mechanical stress on cells from pulse pressure
Estimated temperature rise in tissue from the beam
Duration of safe continuous scanning exposure
Maximum allowable output power for the probe
ultrasound.e: TI is the ratio of acoustic power to the power needed to raise tissue temperature by 1Â°C. A TI of 2 suggests a potential 2Â°C rise.

ultrasound.q: According to ALARA, what should an ultrasound operator do to minimise patient exposure?
ultrasound.a: Use lowest output power and shortest scan time needed
c: Always use the highest frequency probe available
Use lowest output power and shortest scan time needed
Maintain TI above 2.0 to ensure image quality
Apply maximum TGC gain across all depth settings
ultrasound.e: ALARA (As Low As Reasonably Achievable) requires operators to minimise acoustic output and exposure time while maintaining diagnostic quality.

ultrasound.q: CALC: What is the reflection coefficient at an interface where Zâ‚ = 1.63 and Zâ‚‚ = 1.71 MRayl?
Why is coupling gel required between the transducer and the skin surface?
ultrasound.a: To eliminate air which reflects nearly all ultrasound
c: To cool the transducer during prolonged scanning
To eliminate air which reflects nearly all ultrasound
To increase the frequency of the transmitted beam
To reduce electromagnetic interference from the probe
ultrasound.e: Air has very different impedance from tissue, causing ~99.9% reflection. Gel fills the air gap, providing impedance matching.

ultrasound.q: What is harmonic imaging in diagnostic ultrasound?
ultrasound.a: Receiving echoes at twice the transmitted frequency
c: Receiving echoes at twice the transmitted frequency
Using harmonics to measure tissue stiffness
Filtering out all signals below the fundamental
ultrasound.e: Tissue harmonic imaging receives the second harmonic (2fâ‚€) generated by nonlinear propagation in tissue, improving image quality and reducing artifacts.

ultrasound.q: What is the main advantage of tissue harmonic imaging over fundamental imaging?
ultrasound.a: Reduced near-field artifacts and improved contrast
c: Greater penetration depth in obese patients
Reduced near-field artifacts and improved contrast
Higher frame rates for cardiac applications
Wider field of view in sector scanning mode
ultrasound.e: Harmonics build up with depth, so near-field clutter is reduced. The narrower harmonic beam also improves lateral resolution and contrast.

ultrasound.q: CALC: What is the maximum imaging depth for a PRF of 5 kHz in soft tissue?
ultrasound.e: Max depth = c/(2 Ã— PRF) = 1540/(2 Ã— 5000) = 0.154 m = 15.4 cm. The pulse must make the full round trip before the next is sent.

ultrasound.q: What relationship exists between imaging depth and frame rate in B-mode ultrasound?
ultrasound.a: Increasing depth decreases the achievable frame rate
c: Depth and frame rate are completely independent
Increasing depth decreases the achievable frame rate
Increasing depth increases the achievable frame rate
Frame rate depends only on the number of scan lines
ultrasound.e: Greater depth requires longer pulse travel time (lower PRF), reducing the number of lines per second and thus the frame rate.

ultrasound.q: CALC: A B-mode scanner uses 128 lines and a PRF of 6400 Hz. What is the frame rate?
ultrasound.a: 50 frames per second
ultrasound.e: Frame rate = PRF / number of lines = 6400 / 128 = 50 fps.

ultrasound.q: What is speckle in ultrasound imaging?
ultrasound.a: Granular texture from interference of scattered echoes
c: Granular texture from interference of scattered echoes
Electronic noise introduced by the amplifier circuit
Motion blur caused by rapid tissue displacement
ultrasound.e: Speckle arises from constructive and destructive interference of echoes from sub-resolution scatterers. It reduces contrast resolution.

ultrasound.q: What technique reduces speckle noise by averaging multiple frames in ultrasound?
ultrasound.a: Spatial compounding or frame averaging
c: Increasing the dynamic range of the display
Raising the transmit power to maximum level
Applying a high-pass wall filter to signals
ultrasound.e: Spatial compounding acquires images from multiple angles and averages them, reducing speckle while preserving true tissue boundaries.

ultrasound.q: Which artifact causes structures to appear displaced laterally due to beam bending at interfaces?
ultrasound.a: Refraction artifact
ultrasound.e: Refraction occurs when the beam passes obliquely through an interface of different speeds, bending the beam and misplacing echoes laterally.

ultrasound.q: What is the mirror image artifact in ultrasound?
ultrasound.a: Duplication of structures on the far side of a strong reflector
c: Loss of echoes behind a calcified structure in the path
Duplication of structures on the far side of a strong reflector
Bright echoes appearing at regular depth intervals
Colour signal appearing outside the vessel boundaries
ultrasound.e: The mirror artifact occurs when sound reflects off a strong specular reflector (e.g., diaphragm), creating a duplicate image on the opposite side.

ultrasound.q: What is the purpose of a wall filter in Doppler ultrasound?
ultrasound.a: To remove low-frequency signals from vessel wall motion
c: To eliminate high-frequency noise from electronics
To remove low-frequency signals from vessel wall motion
To prevent aliasing at high flow velocity values
To reduce reverberation artifacts near the probe
ultrasound.e: The wall (high-pass) filter removes high-amplitude, low-frequency Doppler shifts caused by tissue and vessel wall movement, revealing blood flow signals.

ultrasound.q: What does power Doppler display compared to conventional colour Doppler?
ultrasound.a: Amplitude of Doppler signal regardless of direction
c: Velocity and direction of blood flow in vessels
Amplitude of Doppler signal regardless of direction
Spectral waveform of flow at a specific point
Tissue displacement caused by acoustic radiation
ultrasound.e: Power Doppler maps the integrated power of the Doppler signal. It is more sensitive to slow flow but does not display velocity or direction.

ultrasound.q: CALC: If intensity at 2 cm depth is reduced by 6 dB, what fraction of original intensity remains?
ultrasound.a: 25% of original intensity
ultrasound.e: 6 dB reduction means intensity ratio = 10^(-6/10) = 0.25, so 25% of the original intensity remains.

ultrasound.q: In a South African radiology department, how often should ultrasound QA tests typically be performed?
ultrasound.a: At least annually with regular user checks
c: Only at initial installation of equipment
At least annually with regular user checks
Every five years per national regulations only
Monthly by the equipment manufacturer only
ultrasound.e: SA guidelines recommend annual comprehensive QA by a medical physicist, supplemented by regular operator checks to ensure consistent image quality.

ultrasound.q: Which QA phantom test assesses axial and lateral resolution of an ultrasound scanner?
ultrasound.a: Imaging wire targets at known separations
c: Measuring Doppler velocity on a string phantom
Imaging wire targets at known separations
Scanning anechoic cylinders for contrast ratio
Recording output power with a radiation force balance
ultrasound.e: Wire target groups in a tissue-equivalent phantom allow measurement of the minimum resolvable distance in both axial and lateral directions.

ultrasound.q: What does the elevation resolution of an ultrasound beam refer to?
ultrasound.a: Resolution in the slice thickness direction of the image
c: Resolution along the direction of beam propagation
Resolution perpendicular to the beam in scan plane
Resolution in the slice thickness direction of the image
Temporal resolution related to the imaging frame rate
ultrasound.e: Elevation (azimuthal/slice thickness) resolution is perpendicular to both axial and lateral directions. It is often the poorest resolution dimension.

ultrasound.q: CALC: An ultrasound beam has a -6 dB intensity drop. By what factor has the amplitude decreased?
ultrasound.a: Factor of 2 (half the original amplitude)
c: Factor of 3 (third of the original amplitude)
ultrasound.e: -6 dB in amplitude corresponds to a factor of 10^(-6/20) = 0.5, so the amplitude is halved.

ultrasound.q: What is the typical frequency range used in diagnostic medical ultrasound imaging?
ultrasound.a: 2 MHz to 18 MHz for most applications
c: 0.5 MHz to 1 MHz for deep imaging only
2 MHz to 18 MHz for most applications
20 MHz to 50 MHz for all clinical scans
100 kHz to 500 kHz for general diagnostics
ultrasound.e: Diagnostic ultrasound typically uses 2-18 MHz. Lower frequencies penetrate deeper while higher frequencies provide better resolution for superficial structures.

ultrasound.q: CALC: The acoustic impedance of tissue A is 1.5 MRayl and tissue B is 1.7 MRayl. What percentage of intensity is transmitted?
ultrasound.e: R = [(1.7-1.5)/(1.7+1.5)]Â² = (0.2/3.2)Â² = 0.0039 = 0.39%. Transmission = 1 - 0.0039 â‰ˆ 99.6%, closest to 99.9% given rounding in similar soft tissues.

ultrasound.q: What is the primary clinical use of M-mode echocardiography?
ultrasound.a: Measuring cardiac chamber dimensions and valve motion
c: Assessing blood flow velocity through heart valves
Measuring cardiac chamber dimensions and valve motion
Evaluating myocardial perfusion with contrast agents
Detecting pericardial calcification on chest imaging
ultrasound.e: M-mode provides excellent temporal resolution for measuring rapidly moving structures like cardiac valves and chamber walls over time.

ultrasound.q: CALC: A 10 MHz linear probe has an aperture of 20 mm. Estimate the near field length in soft tissue.
ultrasound.e: Near field length = DÂ²/(4Î»). Î» = 1540/10Ã—10â¶ = 0.154 mm. D = 20 mm. NF = 20Â²/(4 Ã— 0.154) = 400/0.616 â‰ˆ 649 mm for unfocused. For effective aperture ~10 mm: 100/1.54 â‰ˆ 64.9 mm.

ultrasound.q: What is the significance of the focal zone in an ultrasound beam?
ultrasound.a: Region of narrowest beam width and best lateral resolution
c: Point of maximum acoustic output power in tissue
Region of narrowest beam width and best lateral resolution
Depth where harmonic frequencies are first generated
Area where time gain compensation has greatest effect
ultrasound.e: The focal zone is where the beam converges to its minimum width, providing the best lateral resolution. Structures of interest should be placed at this depth.

ultrasound.q: CALC: A Doppler angle of 0Â° gives a shift of 3.2 kHz. What shift is expected at a 60Â° angle?
ultrasound.a: 1.6 kHz
ultrasound.e: Doppler shift is proportional to cos(Î¸). At 0Â°, cos(0Â°) = 1. At 60Â°, cos(60Â°) = 0.5. So shift = 3.2 Ã— 0.5 = 1.6 kHz.

mri.q: What does T1 relaxation describe?
c: Loss of phase coherence among spins
mri.e: T1 (spin-lattice) relaxation is the exponential recovery of longitudinal magnetization (Mz) as spins release energy to the surrounding lattice after RF excitation.

mri.q: What does T2 relaxation describe?
mri.e: T2 (spin-spin) relaxation is the irreversible loss of transverse magnetization (Mxy) due to dephasing from spin-spin interactions.

mri.q: Which nucleus is most commonly used in clinical MRI?
mri.e: Hydrogen-1 is used because of its high natural abundance in the body (water and fat) and its large gyromagnetic ratio, giving the strongest MR signal.

mri.q: What is the Larmor frequency relationship?
mri.a: Frequency equals gyromagnetic ratio times field strength
c: Frequency equals field strength divided by gyromagnetic ratio
Frequency equals gyromagnetic ratio times field strength
Frequency equals gyromagnetic ratio squared times field
Frequency equals field strength minus gyromagnetic ratio
mri.e: The Larmor equation states omega = gamma x B0, where gamma is the gyromagnetic ratio and B0 is the static magnetic field strength.

mri.q: CALC: What is the Larmor frequency of hydrogen protons at 1.5 T? (gamma = 42.58 MHz/T)
mri.e: Using the Larmor equation: f = gamma x B0 = 42.58 MHz/T x 1.5 T = 63.87 MHz.

mri.q: CALC: What is the Larmor frequency of hydrogen protons at 3.0 T? (gamma = 42.58 MHz/T)
mri.e: Using the Larmor equation: f = gamma x B0 = 42.58 MHz/T x 3.0 T = 127.74 MHz.

mri.q: In a spin echo sequence, what is the purpose of the 180-degree refocusing pulse?
mri.a: To rephase spins and correct for static field inhomogeneities
c: To tip magnetization into the transverse plane initially
To rephase spins and correct for static field inhomogeneities
To completely destroy all remaining transverse magnetization
To selectively saturate fat signal in the imaging volume
mri.e: The 180-degree refocusing pulse reverses the phase accumulated by spins due to static B0 inhomogeneities, producing a true T2-weighted echo rather than T2*.

mri.q: What type of contrast weighting is obtained with short TR and short TE?
mri.e: Short TR maximizes T1 differences between tissues, and short TE minimizes T2 effects, yielding T1-weighted images.

mri.q: What type of contrast weighting is obtained with long TR and long TE?
mri.e: Long TR minimizes T1 contrast between tissues, and long TE allows T2 differences to manifest, producing T2-weighted images.

mri.q: What differentiates gradient echo from spin echo sequences?
mri.a: Gradient echo uses gradient reversal instead of a 180-degree RF pulse
c: Gradient echo always uses a 90-degree excitation RF pulse
Gradient echo uses gradient reversal instead of a 180-degree RF pulse
Gradient echo requires longer TR values than spin echo
Gradient echo cannot produce T1-weighted image contrast
mri.e: Gradient echo sequences form an echo by reversing the readout gradient polarity, rather than using a 180-degree RF refocusing pulse. This makes them faster but sensitive to B0 inhomogeneities (T2* weighting).

mri.q: What is k-space in MRI?
mri.a: The spatial frequency domain where raw MR data is stored
c: The physical space inside the magnet bore of the scanner
The spatial frequency domain where raw MR data is stored
The region of the body selected for imaging acquisition
The calibration area used for coil sensitivity mapping
mri.e: K-space is the Fourier domain representation of the MR image. Each point contains spatial frequency information, and the image is reconstructed via inverse Fourier transform.

mri.q: Which part of k-space primarily determines image contrast?
c: All regions of k-space contribute equally
mri.e: The central region of k-space contains low spatial frequency data which determines overall image contrast and signal intensity, while peripheral k-space encodes fine detail.

mri.q: What is the function of the slice-selection gradient in MRI?
mri.a: To excite only protons within a specific slice location
c: To encode spatial position along the frequency axis
To excite only protons within a specific slice location
To refocus dephasing spins after the RF excitation
To determine the field of view in the phase direction
mri.e: The slice-selection gradient creates a linear variation in B0 so that only protons in a narrow frequency band matching the RF pulse are excited, selecting a specific slice.

mri.q: How does increasing slice-selection gradient strength affect slice thickness?
mri.a: It decreases slice thickness for the same RF bandwidth
c: It increases the slice thickness proportionally
It decreases slice thickness for the same RF bandwidth
It has no effect on the resulting slice thickness
It doubles slice thickness while halving signal
mri.e: A steeper slice-selection gradient maps the same RF bandwidth to a narrower spatial range, resulting in thinner slices.

mri.q: What is the role of the phase-encoding gradient in MRI?
mri.a: To impart position-dependent phase shifts along one axis
c: To select the imaging slice along the z-axis direction
To impart position-dependent phase shifts along one axis
To generate the echo by reversing gradient polarity
To suppress fat signal using spectral differences
mri.e: The phase-encoding gradient is applied briefly before readout, giving spins at different positions along the phase-encode axis different phase shifts for spatial encoding.

mri.q: What is the role of the frequency-encoding (readout) gradient?
mri.a: To make spins at different positions precess at different frequencies
c: To select which slice of tissue is excited by the RF pulse
To make spins at different positions precess at different frequencies
To apply phase differences between successive excitations
To homogenize the static magnetic field across the volume
mri.e: The frequency-encoding gradient is applied during signal readout so spins at different positions along the readout direction precess at unique frequencies for spatial encoding.

mri.q: CALC: If TR = 500 ms and 256 phase-encoding steps, what is the minimum scan time for one average?
mri.e: Scan time = TR x Npe x NEX = 500 ms x 256 x 1 = 128,000 ms = 128 seconds.

mri.q: CALC: If TR = 4000 ms and ETL = 16 with 256 phase-encoding steps, what is the scan time for 1 NEX?
mri.e: For fast spin echo: scan time = TR x (Npe / ETL) x NEX = 4000 ms x (256/16) x 1 = 64,000 ms = 64 seconds.

mri.q: What is the primary safety concern of the static magnetic field (B0)?
mri.a: The projectile effect from ferromagnetic objects
c: Excessive RF energy deposition in patient tissue
The projectile effect from ferromagnetic objects
Peripheral nerve stimulation from rapid switching
Acoustic noise causing potential hearing damage
mri.e: The strong static magnetic field can attract ferromagnetic objects with great force, turning them into dangerous projectiles. This is the most critical safety hazard in MRI.

mri.q: In the ACR MRI safety zones, which zone contains the MRI magnet itself?
mri.e: The ACR defines Zone IV as the MRI scanner room itself, which has the highest magnetic field and strictest access control.

mri.q: What does SAR stand for in MRI safety?
mri.e: SAR measures the rate of RF energy absorption by the body in watts per kilogram. It is a key safety parameter to prevent tissue heating during MRI.

mri.q: How does SAR change when moving from 1.5 T to 3.0 T at the same flip angle?
mri.e: SAR is proportional to B0 squared. Doubling the field strength from 1.5 T to 3.0 T increases SAR by a factor of (3.0/1.5)^2 = 4.

mri.q: CALC: If SAR at 1.5 T is 2.0 W/kg, what is the estimated SAR at 3.0 T with identical parameters?
mri.e: SAR scales with B0^2. From 1.5 T to 3.0 T: SAR(3T) = 2.0 x (3.0/1.5)^2 = 2.0 x 4 = 8.0 W/kg.

mri.q: What causes peripheral nerve stimulation (PNS) during MRI?
c: The strong static magnetic field pulling on nerves
Radiofrequency energy deposited in peripheral tissue
Acoustic vibrations transmitted through the patient table
mri.e: PNS occurs when the rate of change of the magnetic field (dB/dt) from rapidly switching gradients induces electric currents that stimulate peripheral nerves.

mri.q: What is the chemical shift artifact in MRI?
mri.a: Spatial misregistration of fat and water due to frequency differences
c: Bright signal from motion during the acquisition sequence
Spatial misregistration of fat and water due to frequency differences
Signal void caused by metallic implants in the field
Wrap-around of anatomy from outside the field of view
mri.e: Fat and water protons resonate at slightly different frequencies (~3.5 ppm apart). The frequency-encoding gradient misregisters their positions, causing bright/dark bands at fat-water interfaces.

mri.q: CALC: Chemical shift between fat and water at 1.5 T in Hz? (shift = 3.5 ppm, f0 = 63.87 MHz)
mri.e: Chemical shift in Hz = 3.5 ppm x 63.87 MHz = 3.5 x 63.87 = 223.5 Hz, approximately 224 Hz.

mri.q: CALC: Chemical shift between fat and water at 3.0 T in Hz? (shift = 3.5 ppm, f0 = 127.74 MHz)
mri.e: Chemical shift in Hz = 3.5 ppm x 127.74 MHz = 447.1 Hz, approximately 447 Hz.

mri.q: What causes susceptibility artifacts in MRI?
mri.a: Local field distortions at interfaces of different magnetic susceptibilities
c: Misregistration from the chemical shift between fat and water
Local field distortions at interfaces of different magnetic susceptibilities
Incomplete sampling of the outer edges of k-space data
Motion of the patient between successive phase-encoding steps
mri.e: Susceptibility artifacts arise at boundaries between tissues with different magnetic susceptibilities (e.g., air-tissue, metal-tissue), causing local B0 distortions, signal loss, and geometric distortion.

mri.q: What causes aliasing (wrap-around) artifact in MRI?
mri.a: Anatomy outside the FOV being mapped into the image
c: Anatomy outside the FOV being mapped into the image
Patient motion causing ghosting along the phase direction
Gradient nonlinearity distorting the image at the edges
RF interference from external electronic equipment sources
mri.e: Aliasing occurs when the FOV is smaller than the anatomy being imaged. Signals from outside the FOV are undersampled and fold back, violating the Nyquist criterion.

mri.q: In which direction do ghosting artifacts from periodic motion typically appear?
mri.e: Ghosting from periodic motion (cardiac, respiratory) appears along the phase-encoding direction because the motion modulates signal between successive phase-encoding steps.

mri.q: How does increasing NEX (number of signal averages) affect SNR?
mri.a: SNR increases by the square root of NEX
c: SNR increases linearly with the number of averages
SNR increases by the square root of NEX
SNR doubles for each additional signal average
SNR is independent of the number of averages used
mri.e: Signal adds coherently while noise adds randomly, so SNR improves by sqrt(NEX). Doubling NEX from 1 to 2 increases SNR by sqrt(2) = 1.41.

mri.q: CALC: If SNR = 50 with NEX = 1, what is the SNR with NEX = 4?
mri.e: SNR scales with sqrt(NEX). SNR(new) = 50 x sqrt(4) = 50 x 2 = 100.

mri.q: How does doubling the matrix size (256 to 512) in one direction affect SNR, FOV constant?
c: SNR decreases by a factor of four
mri.e: Doubling the matrix halves the voxel dimension, reducing voxel volume by half. Since SNR is proportional to voxel volume, SNR is approximately halved.

mri.q: CALC: A voxel has dimensions 1 mm x 1 mm x 5 mm. What is the voxel volume?
mri.e: Voxel volume = 1 x 1 x 5 = 5 mm cubed. Voxel volume directly affects SNR: larger voxels contain more spins and produce more signal.

mri.q: CALC: Pixel size for a 320 mm FOV with a 256 x 256 matrix?
mri.e: Pixel size = FOV / matrix = 320 mm / 256 = 1.25 mm in each in-plane direction.

mri.q: What is the primary mechanism of T1 shortening by gadolinium contrast agents?
mri.a: Dipole-dipole interaction between Gd electrons and water protons
c: Direct absorption of RF energy by gadolinium chelate molecules
Dipole-dipole interaction between Gd electrons and water protons
Displacement of water molecules from the imaging voxel volume
Chemical bonding of gadolinium ions to tissue protein structures
mri.e: Gadolinium has 7 unpaired electrons creating a strong magnetic moment. The dipole-dipole interaction with nearby water protons enhances T1 relaxation, brightening tissues on T1-weighted images.

mri.q: What adverse effect is associated with gadolinium in patients with severe renal impairment?
mri.e: NSF is a rare but serious condition involving fibrosis of skin, joints, and organs. It is linked to certain gadolinium agents in patients with GFR < 30 mL/min.

mri.q: Which fat suppression technique uses a frequency-selective RF pulse at the fat resonance?
mri.e: Spectral fat saturation applies a frequency-selective RF pulse at the fat resonance frequency (~3.5 ppm from water) to selectively null fat signal before imaging excitation.

mri.q: What inversion time (TI) nulls fat signal in STIR at 1.5 T?
mri.e: In STIR, TI = T1 x ln(2). At 1.5 T, fat T1 is approximately 230 ms, so TI = 0.693 x 230 = 160 ms.

mri.q: CALC: Using TI = T1 x ln(2), what TI nulls CSF in FLAIR? (CSF T1 = 4000 ms)
mri.e: TI = T1 x ln(2) = 4000 x 0.693 = 2772 ms. This is the inversion time used in FLAIR to suppress bright CSF on T2-weighted images.

mri.q: What does diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) primarily measure?
mri.a: The random Brownian motion of water molecules in tissue
c: The blood flow velocity within capillary networks
The random Brownian motion of water molecules in tissue
The rate of contrast agent uptake in tissue
The spin-lattice relaxation rate of intracellular water
mri.e: DWI applies strong gradient pulses that sensitize the MR signal to microscopic water molecule movement. Restricted diffusion (e.g., acute stroke) appears bright on DWI.

mri.q: What does the b-value represent in diffusion-weighted imaging?
mri.a: The degree of diffusion weighting applied by the gradients
c: The baseline signal intensity before gradient application
The degree of diffusion weighting applied by the gradients
The maximum allowed gradient slew rate for the scan
The blood flow contribution to the diffusion signal
mri.e: The b-value (s/mm squared) reflects the strength and timing of diffusion-sensitizing gradients. Higher b-values provide greater diffusion weighting but lower SNR.

mri.q: CALC: S = S0 x exp(-b x ADC). If S0=1000, b=1000, ADC=0.8x10^-3 mm^2/s, what is S?
What is the BOLD effect used in functional MRI (fMRI)?
mri.a: Signal change from varying deoxyhemoglobin concentration in blood
c: Direct measurement of neuronal electrical activity signals
Signal change from varying deoxyhemoglobin concentration in blood
Contrast enhancement from injected paramagnetic agents
Diffusion changes during neural tissue activation events
mri.e: BOLD contrast relies on deoxyhemoglobin being paramagnetic. During neural activation, increased blood flow reduces local deoxyhemoglobin, increasing T2* signal.

mri.q: What MRI sequence is most commonly used for BOLD fMRI?
c: Spin echo with long echo train length
mri.e: GE-EPI provides T2*-sensitivity to the BOLD effect and can acquire entire brain volumes rapidly (every 1-3 seconds) for adequate temporal resolution.

mri.q: What is the main advantage of echo-planar imaging (EPI)?
mri.a: Extremely fast acquisition of an entire image after one excitation
c: Superior spatial resolution compared to spin echo imaging
Extremely fast acquisition of an entire image after one excitation
Complete elimination of all susceptibility-related artifacts
Improved fat suppression without additional preparation pulses
mri.e: EPI can acquire all k-space lines after a single RF excitation by rapidly oscillating the readout gradient, enabling acquisition in 50-100 ms.

mri.q: What is parallel imaging in MRI (e.g., GRAPPA, SENSE)?
mri.a: Using multi-element coil data to undersample k-space and reduce scan time
c: Acquiring multiple slices simultaneously with a single RF pulse
Using multi-element coil data to undersample k-space and reduce scan time
Running two identical sequences in parallel on different channels
Doubling the gradient strength to halve the acquisition time
mri.e: Parallel imaging exploits spatial sensitivity differences between receiver coil elements to reconstruct images from undersampled k-space, reducing scan time by factor R with some SNR penalty.

mri.q: CALC: If parallel imaging acceleration R = 2, how does SNR change vs fully sampled?
mri.a: SNR decreases by a factor of sqrt(2), approximately 0.71x
c: SNR decreases by a factor of 2, exactly 0.50x
SNR decreases by a factor of sqrt(2), approximately 0.71x
SNR remains unchanged with parallel imaging
SNR decreases by a factor of 4, exactly 0.25x
mri.e: Parallel imaging reduces SNR by sqrt(R) from reduced sampling, plus additional g-factor penalty. At minimum, SNR(PI) = SNR(full) / sqrt(2) = 0.71x.

mri.q: The flip angle that maximizes signal in a spoiled gradient echo sequence is called?
mri.e: The Ernst angle (cos alpha = exp(-TR/T1)) gives the optimal flip angle for maximum signal in a spoiled gradient echo at a given TR and tissue T1.

mri.q: CALC: Ernst angle for tissue T1 = 1000 ms at TR = 100 ms? (cos alpha = exp(-TR/T1))
mri.e: cos alpha = exp(-100/1000) = exp(-0.1) = 0.905. alpha = arccos(0.905) = 25.8 degrees, approximately 26 degrees.

mri.q: In MRI safety, what does 'MR Conditional' mean for an implant?
mri.a: The device is safe under specific defined MRI conditions
c: The device is completely unsafe for any MRI examination
The device is safe under specific defined MRI conditions
The device is safe for all MRI field strengths and sequences
The device has not yet been tested for MRI compatibility
mri.e: MR Conditional means the implant poses no known hazard in a specified MRI environment with specified conditions (e.g., field strength, SAR limits, specific coils).

mri.q: What is the main risk of scanning a patient with a cardiac pacemaker in MRI?
mri.a: RF-induced lead heating and potential cardiac stimulation
c: The pacemaker being forcibly pulled from the chest
RF-induced lead heating and potential cardiac stimulation
Complete erasure of all programmed pacemaker parameters
Immediate demagnetization of the pacemaker battery unit
mri.e: Pacemaker leads can act as antennas, concentrating RF energy at the electrode tip. This can cause tissue heating and unintended cardiac stimulation.

mri.q: What is the Dixon technique used for in MRI?
mri.a: Separating fat and water signals using their phase difference
c: Accelerating image acquisition by undersampling k-space
Separating fat and water signals using their phase difference
Correcting geometric distortion from gradient nonlinearity
Measuring tissue perfusion using arterial spin labeling
mri.e: Dixon acquires images when fat and water are in-phase and out-of-phase, then combines them to produce separate water-only and fat-only images.

mri.q: CALC: At 1.5 T, fat/water go in and out of phase with period ~4.4 ms. First out-of-phase TE?
mri.e: The first out-of-phase echo occurs at half the period: TE = 4.4 ms / 2 = 2.2 ms. The first in-phase echo is at TE = 4.4 ms.

mri.q: How does moving from 1.5 T to 3.0 T affect SNR?
mri.e: SNR is approximately linearly proportional to field strength. Moving from 1.5 T to 3.0 T roughly doubles the SNR.

mri.q: What is the purpose of shimming in MRI?
mri.a: To improve the homogeneity of the static magnetic field B0
c: To calibrate the RF transmitter power for patient size
To improve the homogeneity of the static magnetic field B0
To reduce acoustic noise produced by gradient switching
To align the patient correctly at magnet isocentre position
mri.e: Shimming uses passive (metal pieces) and active (shim coils) methods to correct B0 inhomogeneities. Good shimming is critical for fat suppression, EPI, and spectroscopy.

mri.q: CALC: If receiver bandwidth is 32 kHz and matrix is 256, bandwidth per pixel?
mri.e: Bandwidth per pixel = total bandwidth / matrix = 32000 Hz / 256 = 125 Hz/pixel. Lower bandwidth increases SNR but worsens chemical shift artifact.

mri.q: CALC: Chemical shift artifact in pixels = freq shift / BW per pixel. At 3.0 T with 447 Hz shift and 125 Hz/pixel?
mri.e: Chemical shift artifact = 447 Hz / 125 Hz/pixel = 3.6 pixels. Higher bandwidth per pixel reduces the artifact but lowers SNR.

mri.q: What unique challenge does the magnetic field pose for an MR-linac?
mri.a: The electron return effect alters dose distribution at tissue interfaces
c: MR-linac cannot produce diagnostic quality images during treatment
The electron return effect alters dose distribution at tissue interfaces
The linac beam is completely absorbed by the MRI cryostat
Patient positioning is impossible inside the combined bore
mri.e: In an MR-linac, the magnetic field causes secondary electrons to curve (Lorentz force), creating the electron return effect (ERE) at tissue-air interfaces, altering dose distributions.

mri.q: In SA, which regulatory body oversees MRI equipment safety standards?
mri.a: Department of Health radiation control directorate
c: South African Bureau of Standards alone
Department of Health radiation control directorate
Health Professions Council of South Africa only
South African Medical Research Council exclusively
mri.e: In South Africa, MRI safety falls under the Department of Health's radiation control directorate. SAHPRA also regulates medical devices including MRI equipment.

clinical.q: Standard hypofractionated breast RT per FAST-Forward?
clinical.e: FAST-Forward established 26 Gy/5 fx as non-inferior to 40 Gy/15 fx for whole-breast RT. Increasingly adopted in SA centres.

clinical.q: What does the conformity index (CI) measure?
clinical.a: Ratio of prescription isodose volume to target volume
c: Ratio of maximum to minimum dose in the PTV
Ratio of prescription isodose volume to target volume
Percentage of target receiving 95% of dose
Ratio of mean dose to prescribed dose value
clinical.e: CI = V(Rx)/V(PTV). Ideal CI = 1.0. Values >1 indicate dose spill beyond the target.

clinical.q: What does the homogeneity index (HI) measure?
clinical.a: Uniformity of dose distribution within the target
c: Uniformity of dose distribution within the target
Conformity of high-dose region to the PTV volume
Dose gradient steepness outside the target region
Agreement between planned and delivered dose
clinical.e: HI = (D2% - D98%)/D50%. Lower values indicate more homogeneous dose. ICRU 83 defines this formulation.

clinical.q: CALC: PTV volume 250 cc, V(95%) = 275 cc. Conformity index?
Standard curative dose for prostate radiotherapy?
clinical.e: 78 Gy/39 fx is standard conventional dose. Hypofractionated alternatives include 60 Gy/20 fx (PROFIT).

clinical.q: Standard immobilization for H&N radiotherapy?
c: Vacuum bag with arm positioning board
Alpha cradle body mould system only
clinical.e: A thermoplastic mask fixed to an indexed baseplate provides reproducible head and neck positioning.

clinical.q: What is the purpose of a DVH?
clinical.a: To summarise dose distribution in structures as a 2D graph
c: To display the 3D dose cloud in the patient
To summarise dose distribution in structures as a 2D graph
To verify patient positioning before fractions
To calculate the monitor units for delivery
clinical.e: A DVH plots volume (%) vs dose (Gy) for each structure, enabling quantitative plan evaluation.

clinical.q: Standard palliative single-fraction dose for bone metastases?
clinical.e: 8 Gy single fraction provides equivalent pain relief to multi-fraction regimens for uncomplicated bone mets.

clinical.q: Common palliative whole brain RT fractionation?
clinical.e: 20 Gy/5 fx is the most common palliative WBRT regimen. 30 Gy/10 fx for better prognosis patients.

clinical.q: What does a second check (independent MU verification) verify?
clinical.a: That MU agrees with an independent calculation method
c: That the patient is correctly positioned on couch
That MU agrees with an independent calculation method
That the treatment machine output is in tolerance
That the correct patient is on the treatment couch
clinical.e: An independent MU check uses a separate algorithm to verify the TPS calculation, catching systematic errors.

clinical.q: Typical curative cervix cancer dose with concurrent chemo?
clinical.e: Cervix cancer uses 45-50 Gy EBRT with concurrent cisplatin plus HDR brachytherapy boost to EQD2 >85 Gy.

clinical.q: Daily IGRT imaging modality for prostate RT?
clinical.e: CBCT provides 3D soft-tissue visualization for daily prostate verification, accounting for filling changes.

clinical.q: What motion management technique uses external markers to gate the beam?
clinical.e: RPM uses infrared markers to track respiration and gate beam delivery within a defined amplitude window.

clinical.q: DIBH is primarily used for which treatment site?
clinical.e: DIBH inflates the lungs, displacing the heart posteriorly and reducing cardiac dose in left breast RT.

clinical.q: QUANTEC rectal constraint for prostate RT?
clinical.a: V70 less than 20% and V75 less than 15%
c: V50 less than 50% and V60 less than 35%
V70 less than 20% and V75 less than 15%
V65 less than 10% and V70 less than 5%
V60 less than 40% and V70 less than 25%
clinical.e: QUANTEC recommends V70 < 20% and V75 < 15% for the rectum to limit grade 2+ rectal toxicity.

clinical.q: Standard SRS dose for a single brain metastasis < 2 cm?
clinical.e: RTOG 90-05 established 24 Gy for tumors < 2 cm in single-fraction SRS.

clinical.q: SAHPRA incident report threshold for RT dose deviation?
clinical.a: Greater than 5% deviation from prescribed dose
c: Greater than 2% deviation from prescribed dose
Greater than 5% deviation from prescribed dose
Greater than 10% deviation from prescribed dose
clinical.e: In South Africa, SAHPRA requires reporting radiation incidents where delivered dose deviates >5% from prescribed.

clinical.q: Standard peripheral lung SBRT dose per RTOG 0236?
clinical.e: 54 Gy/3 fx (BED10 = 151.2 Gy) is the standard for peripheral early-stage lung SBRT.

clinical.q: CALC: Lung SBRT 54 Gy in 3 fx. BED10?
What plan metric assesses dose fall-off outside the target?
clinical.e: GI = V50%/V100% measures dose fall-off steepness. Lower GI means better sparing of surrounding tissue.

clinical.q: Standard concurrent chemo for cervix cancer RT?
clinical.e: Weekly cisplatin 40 mg/m2 is the standard concurrent agent, improving survival over RT alone.

clinical.q: Concurrent chemotherapy for GBM (Stupp protocol)?
clinical.e: Stupp protocol: 60 Gy/30 fx with concurrent daily temozolomide 75 mg/m2 followed by adjuvant temozolomide.

clinical.q: Standard curative H&N dose for oropharyngeal SCC?
clinical.e: 70 Gy/35 fx to primary GTV with 54-56 Gy to elective nodes is standard curative H&N RT.

clinical.q: CALC: H&N SIB delivers 70 Gy/35 fx and 56 Gy/35 fx. Dose per fraction to PTV56?
clinical.e: 56/35 = 1.6 Gy per fraction to the elective nodal volume.

clinical.q: What does SIB stand for in radiotherapy?
clinical.e: SIB delivers different dose levels to different PTVs simultaneously in each fraction.

clinical.q: Typical lung V20 constraint in thoracic RT?
clinical.e: Bilateral lung V20 < 30-35% reduces radiation pneumonitis risk. Mean lung dose < 20 Gy also used.

clinical.q: What is adaptive radiotherapy?
clinical.a: Modifying the plan during treatment based on anatomical changes
c: Adjusting fraction size based on tumour response
Modifying the plan during treatment based on anatomical changes
Using fixed margins for all setup uncertainties
Planning with multiple beam angles for conformity
clinical.e: Adaptive RT involves replanning to account for tumour shrinkage, weight loss, or organ changes during treatment.

clinical.q: CALC: D2%=107%, D98%=95%, D50%=102%. Homogeneity index (ICRU 83)?
Recommended PTV margin for prostate with daily CBCT?
clinical.e: With daily CBCT, typical prostate margins are 5-7 mm except 3 mm posteriorly to spare the rectum.

clinical.q: CALC: Prostate SBRT 36.25 Gy/5 fx. BED for alpha/beta = 1.5 Gy?
What is the Van Herk margin recipe formula?
clinical.e: Van Herk: M = 2.5 Sigma + 0.7 sigma ensures CTV dose >= 95% for 90% of the population.

clinical.q: CALC: Systematic error 3 mm, random error 2 mm. PTV margin (Van Herk)?
What is SGRT (surface-guided radiation therapy)?
clinical.a: Real-time optical surface tracking for patient positioning
c: Stereotactic gated radiation therapy with fiducials
Real-time optical surface tracking for patient positioning
Standard guided radiotherapy using CBCT imaging
clinical.e: SGRT (AlignRT, Catalyst) uses cameras to track the patient surface in real-time for setup and monitoring.

clinical.q: What is the CTV-PTV margin purpose?
clinical.a: To account for setup uncertainties and organ motion
c: To account for setup uncertainties and organ motion
To compensate for beam penumbra effects
To allow for dose calculation grid resolution
clinical.e: The CTV-to-PTV margin accounts for geometric uncertainties: setup error, organ motion, intrafraction movement.

clinical.q: Standard GBM radiotherapy dose (Stupp protocol)?
clinical.e: 60 Gy/30 fx with concurrent temozolomide for newly diagnosed GBM.

clinical.q: Primary advantage of VMAT over fixed-field IMRT?
clinical.a: Faster treatment delivery with continuous arc rotation
c: Better dose conformity in all clinical scenarios
Faster treatment delivery with continuous arc rotation
Lower integral dose to the patient body overall
Simpler treatment planning and optimization process
clinical.e: VMAT delivers during continuous rotation with variable dose rate, MLC, and speed, reducing time from ~15 to ~2-5 min.

clinical.q: What is the purpose of bolus in radiotherapy?
clinical.a: To increase surface dose by reducing skin-sparing
c: To shield critical structures from the beam
To increase surface dose by reducing skin-sparing
To improve beam penetration to deeper targets
To compensate for tissue heterogeneity effects
clinical.e: Tissue-equivalent bolus shifts dose buildup to the surface, useful for chest wall and superficial treatments.

clinical.q: Standard WBRT dose for brain metastases?
clinical.e: 30 Gy/10 fx is the most common WBRT regimen. 20 Gy/5 fx used for poor prognosis.

clinical.q: Hypofractionated prostate RT dose per CHHiP trial?
clinical.e: CHHiP established 60 Gy/20 fx as non-inferior to 74 Gy/37 fx for localized prostate cancer.

clinical.q: Role of a physics plan check in the treatment planning workflow?
clinical.a: Verify plan deliverability, MU accuracy, and constraints
c: Contour all target volumes and organs at risk
Verify plan deliverability, MU accuracy, and constraints
Prescribe dose and select fractionation scheme
Perform daily image guidance for patient setup
clinical.e: Physics plan check reviews MU, dose constraints, beam parameters, and deliverability before physician approval.

clinical.q: What is the 4R framework in radiobiology for fractionation?
clinical.e: The 4Rs explain why fractionation benefits treatment: tumour reoxygenation/reassortment improve kill, tissue repair reduces toxicity.

clinical.q: Standard patient setup for breast radiotherapy?
clinical.a: Supine on breast board with ipsilateral arm raised
c: Prone on belly board with arms at sides
Supine on breast board with ipsilateral arm raised
Supine flat with both arms at sides
clinical.e: Supine on breast board with ipsilateral arm raised provides optimal access for tangential fields.

clinical.q: Most critical organ constraint for H&N IMRT plan evaluation?
clinical.e: Spinal cord max (typically < 45 Gy) is most critical as myelopathy is devastating and irreversible.

clinical.q: What verification is done on the first day of treatment?
clinical.a: Setup images compared to DRR or reference CT
c: Setup images compared to DRR or reference CT
Patient blood work and toxicity assessment
clinical.e: First-day images (portal or CBCT) are compared to reference to confirm correct positioning.

clinical.q: CALC: EQD2 of 8 Gy single fraction (alpha/beta = 10)?

statistics.q: What does a p-value of 0.03 indicate?
statistics.a: 3% probability of result under null hypothesis
c: 3% chance the alternative hypothesis is true
3% probability of result under null hypothesis
statistics.e: The p-value is the probability of observing the data (or more extreme) assuming the null hypothesis is true.

statistics.q: Which measure of central tendency is most affected by outliers?
statistics.a: Arithmetic mean
statistics.e: The arithmetic mean uses every value in its calculation, so extreme outliers pull it toward them.

statistics.q: In a normal distribution, what percentage falls within +/-2 standard deviations?
statistics.e: The empirical rule: ~68.3% within +/-1 sigma, ~95.4% within +/-2 sigma, ~99.7% within +/-3 sigma.

statistics.q: A Type I error in hypothesis testing is also known as:
statistics.a: A false positive result
statistics.e: A Type I error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but is incorrectly rejected. Its probability is denoted alpha.

statistics.q: A Type II error in hypothesis testing is also known as:
statistics.a: A false negative result
statistics.e: A Type II error occurs when the null hypothesis is false but fails to be rejected. Its probability is denoted beta.

statistics.q: What statistical distribution best models radioactive decay counting?
statistics.a: Poisson distribution
statistics.e: Radioactive decay is a random process with a known average rate and rare individual events, well modeled by the Poisson distribution.

statistics.q: For Poisson-distributed radiation counts, the standard deviation equals:
statistics.a: The square root of the mean counts
c: The square root of the mean counts
Half of the mean count value
The mean divided by sample size
statistics.e: For a Poisson distribution, variance equals the mean, so standard deviation sigma = sqrt(mu).

statistics.q: CALC: A detector records 10,000 counts. What is the standard deviation?
statistics.a: 100 counts
statistics.e: For Poisson statistics, sigma = sqrt(N) = sqrt(10000) = 100 counts. Percent uncertainty is 1%.

statistics.q: CALC: If 2500 counts are recorded, what is the percentage uncertainty (1 sigma)?
statistics.e: sigma = sqrt(2500) = 50. Percentage uncertainty = (50/2500) x 100% = 2.0%.

statistics.q: What does a 95% confidence interval mean?
statistics.a: 95% of such intervals contain the true value
c: The true value is 95% likely in this interval
95% of such intervals contain the true value
There is a 5% chance the result is wrong
statistics.e: A 95% CI means if the experiment were repeated many times, 95% of constructed intervals would contain the true parameter.

statistics.q: Which test compares means of two independent groups with normal data?
statistics.a: Independent samples t-test
statistics.e: The independent samples t-test compares means of two independent normally distributed groups.

statistics.q: When should a paired t-test be used instead of an independent t-test?
statistics.a: When measurements are taken on the same subjects
c: When sample sizes are unequal between groups
When measurements are taken on the same subjects
When the data distribution is clearly skewed
When comparing more than two group means
statistics.e: A paired t-test is used when measurements are correlated, such as before/after on the same subjects.

statistics.q: What is the purpose of ANOVA?
statistics.a: To compare means across three or more groups
c: To test correlation between two variables
To compare means across three or more groups
To compare variances of two populations
To assess normality of a data distribution
statistics.e: ANOVA tests whether the means of three or more groups differ significantly, avoiding multiple pairwise t-tests.

statistics.q: What does the chi-square test evaluate?
statistics.a: Whether observed frequencies differ from expected
c: Whether two continuous means are different
Whether observed frequencies differ from expected
Whether a dataset follows a t-distribution
Whether sample variance equals population variance
statistics.e: The chi-square test compares observed categorical frequencies to expected frequencies to determine statistical significance.

statistics.q: In linear regression, what does the R-squared value represent?
statistics.a: Proportion of variance explained by the model
c: Proportion of variance explained by the model
The slope of the best-fit regression line
The correlation coefficient of raw data
The probability the regression is significant
statistics.e: R-squared indicates the fraction of total variance in the dependent variable that is explained by the regression model.

statistics.q: What does a Bland-Altman plot display?
statistics.a: Differences vs. averages of two measurement methods
c: Differences vs. averages of two measurement methods
statistics.e: A Bland-Altman plot shows the difference between two methods against their average, revealing systematic bias and limits of agreement.

statistics.q: On a Bland-Altman plot, the limits of agreement are typically:
statistics.a: Mean difference +/- 1.96 standard deviations
statistics.e: The 95% limits of agreement are mean difference +/- 1.96 SD, encompassing 95% of the differences between methods.

statistics.q: What does the area under the ROC curve (AUC) represent?
statistics.a: Overall diagnostic accuracy of the test
c: The test sensitivity at optimal threshold
The test specificity at optimal threshold
Overall diagnostic accuracy of the test
The positive predictive value of the test
statistics.e: AUC summarizes the test's ability to discriminate between positive and negative cases. AUC = 1.0 is perfect, 0.5 is chance.

statistics.q: Sensitivity of a diagnostic test is defined as:
statistics.a: Proportion of true positives among all diseased
c: Proportion of true positives among all diseased
Proportion of true negatives among all healthy
Proportion of true positives among test positives
Proportion of true negatives among test negatives
statistics.e: Sensitivity = TP/(TP+FN), the ability to correctly identify those with the condition.

statistics.q: Specificity of a diagnostic test is defined as:
statistics.a: Proportion of true negatives among all healthy
c: Proportion of true positives among all diseased
Proportion of true negatives among all healthy
Proportion of true negatives among test negatives
Proportion of true positives among test positives
statistics.e: Specificity = TN/(TN+FP), the ability to correctly identify those without the condition.

statistics.q: CALC: Sensitivity 90%, specificity 80%, 1000 patients, 10% prevalence. How many false positives?
statistics.e: 900 healthy x (1 - 0.80) = 900 x 0.20 = 180 false positives.

statistics.q: What is the standard error of the mean (SEM)?
statistics.a: Standard deviation divided by sqrt(n)
c: Variance divided by sample size n
statistics.e: SEM = sigma/sqrt(n) quantifies the uncertainty in the sample mean. Larger samples yield smaller SEM.

statistics.q: CALC: If sigma = 12 and n = 36, what is the standard error of the mean?
statistics.e: SEM = sigma/sqrt(n) = 12/sqrt(36) = 12/6 = 2.0.

statistics.q: CALC: Two independent uncertainties are 3% and 4%. Combined uncertainty?
statistics.e: For independent uncertainties in quadrature: sqrt(3^2 + 4^2) = sqrt(25) = 5.0%.

statistics.q: According to the GUM, what are the two types of uncertainty evaluation?
statistics.a: Type A (statistical) and Type B (other methods)
c: Type A (statistical) and Type B (other methods)
Type A (random) and Type B (systematic only)
Type A (absolute) and Type B (relative values)
statistics.e: GUM defines Type A based on statistical analysis of repeated observations and Type B based on other information like calibration certificates.

statistics.q: In the GUM framework, Type A uncertainty is evaluated by:
statistics.a: Statistical analysis of repeated measurements
statistics.e: Type A uncertainty is obtained from statistical analysis of a series of observations, typically the standard deviation of the mean.

statistics.q: What is the coverage factor k for a 95% confidence expanded uncertainty?
statistics.a: k = 2 (approximately 1.96)
statistics.e: For a normal distribution, k = 1.96 (often rounded to 2) gives a 95% confidence interval.

statistics.q: In a Shewhart control chart, the upper control limit (UCL) is set at:
statistics.a: Mean + 3 standard deviations
statistics.e: Shewhart charts use +/-3 sigma limits (99.7%). Points beyond these indicate an out-of-control process.

statistics.q: On a control chart, which pattern suggests a systematic drift?
statistics.a: Seven consecutive points on one side of the mean
c: One point beyond the 3-sigma control limits
Seven consecutive points on one side of the mean
Two consecutive points within the 1-sigma zone
Alternating points above and below the mean
statistics.e: A run of seven or more consecutive points on one side (Western Electric rule) suggests a process shift or drift.

statistics.q: Difference between tolerance limits and action levels in QA?
statistics.a: Tolerance triggers investigation; action halts clinical use
c: Tolerance halts clinical use; action triggers investigation
Tolerance triggers investigation; action halts clinical use
Both trigger investigation but at different intervals
Tolerance is for daily QA; action is for annual only
statistics.e: Tolerance limits require investigation if exceeded. Action levels are stricter and require halting clinical use until corrective action.

statistics.q: CALC: Linac output mean 1.000 Gy, SD 0.005 Gy. Action level at +/-3 sigma?
CALC: Uncertainty in dose is 2%, in volume is 3%. Combined uncertainty?
statistics.e: Combined = sqrt(2^2 + 3^2) = sqrt(13) = 3.6%. Independent uncertainties combine in quadrature.

statistics.q: What is statistical power in hypothesis testing?
statistics.a: Probability of correctly rejecting a false H0
c: Probability of correctly accepting a true H0
Probability of correctly rejecting a false H0
Probability of making a Type I error overall
Probability of the test statistic being large
statistics.e: Power = 1 - beta. Higher power means greater chance of detecting a true effect.

statistics.q: Increasing sample size primarily:
statistics.a: Decreases standard error and narrows CI
c: Decreases standard error and narrows CI
Increases the probability of Type I error
Changes the underlying population mean value
statistics.e: Larger samples reduce SEM = sigma/sqrt(n), narrowing confidence intervals and increasing statistical power.

statistics.q: CALC: Background 400 counts, gross 1600 counts. Net count uncertainty?
statistics.a: 44.7 counts
statistics.e: Net = 1200. Uncertainty = sqrt(1600 + 400) = sqrt(2000) = 44.7 counts.

statistics.q: What does the Pearson correlation coefficient r measure?
statistics.a: Strength of linear relationship between two variables
c: Strength of linear relationship between two variables
Proportion of variance explained by regression
Statistical significance of the mean difference
statistics.e: Pearson's r measures strength and direction of a linear relationship between two continuous variables, ranging from -1 to +1.

statistics.q: CALC: Poisson mean 225 counts. What is the 95% confidence range?
statistics.a: 195.6 to 254.4 counts

statistics.q: What nonparametric test is equivalent to the independent samples t-test?
statistics.a: Mann-Whitney U test
statistics.e: The Mann-Whitney U test (Wilcoxon rank-sum) is the nonparametric alternative for comparing two independent groups.

statistics.q: CALC: Measurement yields 50.0 +/- 0.5 cm. Relative uncertainty?
statistics.e: Relative uncertainty = (0.5/50.0) x 100% = 1.0%.

statistics.q: When comparing two dosimetry methods, which analysis is preferred over correlation?
statistics.a: Bland-Altman analysis of agreement
statistics.e: Bland-Altman reveals bias and limits of agreement. Correlation only shows association, not agreement.

anatomy.q: Spinal cord TD 5/5 tolerance dose in conventional fractionation?
anatomy.e: The spinal cord TD 5/5 is approximately 45-50 Gy. Exceeding this risks radiation myelopathy.

anatomy.q: Primary dose-limiting organ in head and neck radiotherapy?
anatomy.e: The spinal cord is the primary dose-limiting structure due to the risk of myelopathy.

anatomy.q: The optic chiasm TD 5/5 tolerance dose is approximately?
anatomy.e: The optic chiasm TD 5/5 is approximately 50-54 Gy. Exceeding this can cause optic neuropathy and vision loss.

anatomy.q: Which cervical lymph node level is in the posterior triangle?
anatomy.e: Level V nodes are in the posterior triangle, bounded by SCM posterior border, trapezius, and clavicle.

anatomy.q: The brainstem TD 5/5 tolerance dose is approximately?
anatomy.e: The brainstem TD 5/5 is approximately 50-54 Gy. Damage can cause cranial nerve palsies and ataxia.

anatomy.q: Which organ is most susceptible to radiation-induced xerostomia?
anatomy.e: The parotid produces most stimulated saliva and is highly radiosensitive. IMRT sparing reduces xerostomia.

anatomy.q: Mean parotid dose constraint per QUANTEC to preserve salivary function?
anatomy.e: QUANTEC recommends mean parotid dose < 25-26 Gy to at least one gland to preserve salivary function.

anatomy.q: The brachial plexus is formed by ventral rami of which spinal roots?
anatomy.e: The brachial plexus is formed by C5-T1 ventral rami. Critical in breast, lung, and head and neck RT planning.

anatomy.q: What is the TD 5/5 tolerance dose for the whole liver?
anatomy.e: The whole liver TD 5/5 is approximately 30-35 Gy. Exceeding this risks radiation-induced liver disease (RILD).

anatomy.q: Which structure divides the right lung into three lobes?
anatomy.e: The right lung has oblique and horizontal fissures creating three lobes. The left has only the oblique fissure.

anatomy.q: Which heart substructure gets highest dose in left breast tangential RT?
anatomy.e: The LAD lies along the anterior interventricular groove and receives the highest cardiac dose in left breast tangents.

anatomy.q: Superior border of cervical lymph node level II per RTOG?
anatomy.a: Base of skull at the jugular fossa
c: Base of skull at the jugular fossa
anatomy.e: Level II extends from skull base at the jugular fossa superiorly to the hyoid bone inferiorly.

anatomy.q: Femoral head dose constraint per QUANTEC in pelvic RT?
anatomy.e: QUANTEC recommends V50 < 5% for femoral heads to minimize avascular necrosis risk.

anatomy.q: Which organ demonstrates the greatest respiratory motion?
