anatomy.e: Lower lobe tumors exhibit the greatest respiratory motion, often exceeding 2 cm SI due to diaphragmatic excursion.

anatomy.q: Cochlea tolerance dose to minimize sensorineural hearing loss?
anatomy.e: Keeping mean cochlear dose below 45 Gy reduces sensorineural hearing loss risk in posterior fossa treatments.

anatomy.q: Structure immediately anterior to the rectum in male patients?
anatomy.e: The prostate and seminal vesicles lie immediately anterior to the rectum, making the anterior rectal wall a key OAR.

anatomy.q: Primary endpoint for whole kidney radiation tolerance?
anatomy.e: Radiation nephropathy is the primary concern. The bilateral kidney TD 5/5 is approximately 23 Gy.

anatomy.q: The whole kidney TD 5/5 tolerance dose is approximately?
anatomy.e: Bilateral kidney TD 5/5 is approximately 23 Gy. At least two-thirds of one kidney should be spared.

anatomy.q: Which lymph node level lies in the submandibular triangle?
anatomy.e: Level IB nodes lie in the submandibular triangle, bounded by the digastric muscle and mandible.

anatomy.q: In prostate RT, which direction does the prostate move most with rectal filling?
anatomy.e: Rectal filling causes predominantly AP prostate motion. Daily image guidance addresses this.

anatomy.q: The hippocampus is a critical avoidance structure in which technique?
anatomy.e: HA-WBRT spares the hippocampus to preserve memory. RTOG 0933 demonstrated improved neurocognitive outcomes.

anatomy.q: Where is the hippocampus located anatomically?
anatomy.e: The hippocampus is in the medial temporal lobe, critical for memory formation.

anatomy.q: The lens of the eye TD 5/5 tolerance dose is approximately?
anatomy.e: The lens is the most radiosensitive eye structure with TD 5/5 of approximately 10 Gy.

anatomy.q: Which contouring guideline defines CTV for intact cervical cancer?
anatomy.e: EMBRACE provides ESTRO-based guidelines for cervical cancer CTV contouring, incorporating MRI-based adaptive planning.

anatomy.q: The esophagus TD 5/5 for whole organ irradiation?
anatomy.e: The esophagus TD 5/5 is approximately 55-60 Gy for stricture/perforation. It is a serial organ.

anatomy.q: In breast RT, the chest wall extends from skin to which deep boundary?
anatomy.a: Anterior surface of the parietal pleura
c: Anterior surface of the parietal pleura
anatomy.e: The chest wall CTV extends from skin to the anterior parietal pleura, including pectoralis muscles and ribs.

anatomy.q: Which axillary lymph node level lies lateral to the pectoralis minor?
anatomy.e: Level I is lateral/inferior to pectoralis minor. Level II is deep to it. Level III is medial.

anatomy.q: Larynx dose constraint to preserve voice quality?
anatomy.e: Mean larynx dose < 40-45 Gy helps preserve voice quality and reduce edema in non-target larynx treatments.

anatomy.q: Which pelvic organ is classified as a parallel organ?
anatomy.e: The bladder is parallel: functional tolerance depends on irradiated volume rather than max point dose.

anatomy.q: RTOG prostate CTV typically includes which structures?
anatomy.a: Prostate gland and proximal seminal vesicles
c: Prostate gland and proximal seminal vesicles
anatomy.e: For intermediate-risk, the RTOG atlas typically includes prostate and proximal SVs. Extent depends on risk group.

anatomy.q: Which cranial nerve passes through the superior orbital fissure?
anatomy.e: CN III, IV, V1, and VI pass through the superior orbital fissure. The optic nerve uses the optic canal.

anatomy.q: Typical SI extent of liver motion due to respiration?
anatomy.e: The liver typically moves 1-2 cm SI with respiration due to diaphragmatic motion. Important for liver SBRT.

anatomy.q: The cerebellum is located in which cranial fossa?
anatomy.e: The cerebellum occupies the posterior cranial fossa, below the tentorium cerebelli and posterior to the brainstem.

anatomy.q: Which atlas divides the neck into lymph node levels I through VII?
anatomy.a: RTOG head and neck nodal contouring atlas
c: RTOG head and neck nodal contouring atlas
anatomy.e: The RTOG H&N nodal atlas provides CT-based guidelines for delineating cervical lymph node levels I-VII.

anatomy.q: Small bowel dose constraint per QUANTEC for pelvic RT?
anatomy.e: QUANTEC recommends V45 < 195 cc for individual small bowel loops to limit grade 3+ toxicity.

anatomy.q: Which structure forms the posterior boundary of the prostate on CT?
anatomy.e: The anterior rectal wall forms the posterior prostate boundary on CT. Denonvilliers fascia is not typically visible.

anatomy.q: The penile bulb is contoured as avoidance structure to reduce which toxicity?
anatomy.e: Sparing the penile bulb during prostate RT may help preserve erectile function per RTOG guidelines.

anatomy.q: Which structure separates level IIA from level IIB cervical nodes?
anatomy.e: Level IIA is anterior/medial to the IJV, level IIB is posterior. Important for selective neck dissection planning.

anatomy.q: The mandible is at risk for which late radiation effect?
anatomy.e: Osteoradionecrosis of the mandible occurs when bone receives >60-70 Gy, especially with post-RT dental extractions.

anatomy.q: In lung SBRT, the proximal bronchial tree extends how far from the carina?
anatomy.a: 2 cm from the carina and main bronchi
c: 2 cm from the carina and main bronchi
anatomy.e: RTOG defines the proximal bronchial tree as carina, main bronchi, and lobar bronchi within 2 cm. Critical in central lung SBRT.

anatomy.q: Which heart structure is most anterior and closest to the chest wall?
anatomy.e: The right ventricle forms the majority of the anterior cardiac surface. However, the LAD territory is most relevant in breast RT.

anatomy.q: The stomach whole organ TD 5/5 tolerance dose is approximately?
anatomy.e: The whole stomach TD 5/5 is approximately 50 Gy for ulceration and perforation.

anatomy.q: Most important OAR in SRS for vestibular schwannoma?
anatomy.e: Functional hearing preservation depends on cochlear dose. Keeping it low is essential for maintaining hearing after SRS.

anatomy.q: ESTRO-ACROP cranial border of the breast CTV?
anatomy.a: Second rib insertion or inferior clavicular head
c: First rib insertion at the sternum
Second rib insertion or inferior clavicular head
Third rib insertion at the sternum
anatomy.e: ESTRO-ACROP defines the cranial breast CTV border at approximately the second rib insertion or inferior clavicular head.

anatomy.q: Cervical lymph node level VI is in which anatomical compartment?
anatomy.e: Level VI is in the anterior central compartment from hyoid to sternal notch, containing pretracheal and paratracheal nodes.

anatomy.q: Typical bladder filling protocol for pelvic radiotherapy?
anatomy.a: Comfortably full with consistent fluid intake
c: Comfortably full with consistent fluid intake
anatomy.e: A comfortably full bladder displaces small bowel out of the field and provides consistent positioning.

anatomy.q: Retropharyngeal lymph nodes are most relevant in which cancer?
anatomy.e: Retropharyngeal nodes are a common metastatic site in nasopharyngeal carcinoma and must be included in the CTV.

anatomy.q: Which pelvic structure is most susceptible to late rectal bleeding from RT?
anatomy.e: The anterior rectal wall receives highest dose in prostate RT and is the most common site of radiation telangiectasia.

anatomy.q: Brachial plexus maximum dose tolerance per QUANTEC?
anatomy.e: QUANTEC recommends brachial plexus max dose < 66 Gy to limit plexopathy risk in breast, lung, and H&N RT.

anatomy.q: Which atlas provides elective nodal CTV guidelines for anal canal cancer?
anatomy.e: RTOG 0529 provides the standard atlas for inguinal, iliac, and presacral nodal CTVs in anal canal chemoradiation.
